child.pub-comments: "...Higher-level branchings are disputed. The most common current view has Huastecan splitting off first, then Yucatecan; then the remaining groups diverge. While this is plausible , it requires confirmation. The position of Huastecan has been in dispute, but it now seems clear that it was first break-off. Some had placed it closer to Greater Tzeltalan and/or Yucatecan based on what appeared to be shared innovations among these languages, but some of these reasons no longer exist" (Campbell, Kaufman, 1985:188).
"The Mayan family consists of 31 languages, spoken principally in Guaternala and Southern Mexico. Two are now extinct: Chiconuceltec and Choltí" (Campbell, Kaufman, 1985:187).
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle & Terrence Kaufman. 1985. Mayan Linguistics: Where are we Now?, Annual Review of Antropology, vol. 14, 187-198.

child.pub-comments: "…Kaufman has recently descovered a dialect of Huastec, which he calls Otontepec…" (Campbell, Kaufman, 1985:188).
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle & Terrence Kaufman. 1985. Mayan Linguistics: Where are we Now?, Annual Review of Antropology, vol. 14, 187-198.
child.geography: "…Including among others the towns of Chontla and Chinampa in Veracruz."
